items.title: Oracle engages its lawyers and JavaScript turns 29
items.content:
#â€‹715 â€” December 5, 2024

Read on the Web

ğŸ—“ï¸ If you missed last week's issue, don't worry, it didn't exist â€“ we took a week off for Thanksgiving! We're now back all the way through to the Christmas break :-)
__
Your editor, Peter Cooper

JavaScriptâ„¢ Weekly

Deno v. Oracle: Cancelling the JavaScript Trademark â€” Did you know Oracle formally owns the â€˜JavaScriptâ€™ trademark? There have been a few efforts to change this over the years but Oracle isnâ€™t listening, so the Deno team formally filed a petition to cancel the trademark.

Deno

âš–ï¸ And, as of this week, it looks like Oracle is lawyering up to defend it [PDF].

ğŸ‚Â JavaScript Turns 29 Years Old â€” If youâ€™re wondering why Oracle has the JavaScript trademark, it's because Sun owned the name and Oracle acquired Sun (which is also why it owns Java). As someone who was posting inane questions in comp.lang.javascript in 1996, this news makes me feel old â€“ no-one could have anticipated what JavaScript would beÂ today.

Netscape and Sun Microsystems

Add Excel-like Spreadsheet Functionality to Your JavaScript Apps â€” SpreadJS is the industry-leading JavaScript spreadsheet for adding advanced spreadsheet features to your enterprise apps. Build finance, analysis, budget, and other apps. Excel I/O, 500+ calc functions, tables, charts, and more. View demosÂ now.

SpreadJS from MESCIUS inc sponsor

Astro 5.0: The Web Framework for Content-Driven Sites â€” Astro has taken the front-end world by storm and v5.0 keeps up its rapid pace of development. Content Layer makes it easy to load content from any source and Server Islands can combine cached, static content with dynamic content. Thereâ€™s now a type-safe way to manage environment variables and Vite 6 is along for the ride too. You can play with Astro 5 using the astro.new site.

The Astro Team

Take the State of JavaScript 2024 Survey â€” Each year, Devographics runs a popular survey to see what JS features and tools you know about, use, and love/hate. Itâ€™s structured such that you can learn something just from taking it and the results are always interesting (see 2023â€™s). Itâ€™s open for a few more days, despite what the pageÂ says. (Or â–¶ï¸ watch someone else takingÂ it?)

Devographics

IN BRIEF:

  • npmjs.com has a 'new, streamlined search experience. It's mostly a tweaking of the 'sort' options â€“ so take a search like this one for 'svg', you can now sort by recent download counts and dependencyÂ levels.

  • TC39 News: Import Sync (explained here) is being promoted to stage 1, Error.isError moves to stage 3, and Intl.DurationFormat moves to stage 4.

  • ğŸ„ Adrian Roselli has a roundup of development-themed advent calendars for you to enjoy this month, including Advent of TypeScript. 'Tis theÂ season!

  • Porffor is an interesting ahead-of-time JavaScript compiler, now complete with a snazzy newÂ homepage.

  • test262.fyi presents a technical view of how different JS engines fare on the official ECMAScript conformanceÂ suite.

RELEASES:

  • TypeScript 5.7 â€“ The final release of the typed JavaScriptÂ superset.

  • Node.js v22.12.0 (LTS) â€“ A noteworthy release as it's the first Node LTS release with require(esm) enabled byÂ default.

  • Radon IDE 1.0 â€“ Turn VS Code or Cursor into a fully-fledged React NativeÂ IDE.

  • Prisma 6 â€“ Powerful Node.js + TypeScript ORM.

  • Vite 6.0, React Router 7.0, Undici 7, ESLint v9.16.0, Meteor.js 3.1, Relay 18.2, Tailwind CSS v4.0 Beta, Redux Toolkit 2.4, Bun 1.1.38, NeutralinoJS 5.5

ğŸ“’Â Articles & Tutorials

ğŸ¤–Â Using Transformers.js for AI in the Browser â€” Transformers.js is a seriously impressive project we link from time to time that lets you run pretrained machine learning models in the browser. Hereâ€™s a practical look at actually playing with it yourself rightÂ now.

Raymond Camden

Working with JavaScript's Scheduler API â€” A look at an API only available in Chromium/Edge for now, but that promises a way to prioritize and control task execution in a more refined way than was possible tillÂ now.

Trevor I. Lasn

Quokka V2: Deeper Code Insights & Interactive Timeline with New UI â€” The #1 JavaScript scratchpad just got better! Quokka v2 brings a new UI, interactive timeline, and tools for fasterÂ prototyping.

Wallaby Team sponsor

ğŸ“‰Â How To Improve 'Interaction to Next Paint' in React Apps â€” Interaction to Next Paint (INP) is a Web performance metric based on the responsiveness of an app to user interactions â€“ Google uses it as part of its ranking mechanism. Jacob offers up advice and resources for improving your INP scores in ReactÂ apps.

Jacob 'Kurt' GroÃŸ

How Airtable Scaled TypeScript to Thousands of Projects â€” â€œToday we have nearly 3000 TypeScript projects. Thatâ€™s why weâ€™re sharing our journey to so many projects, and how it reduced our typechecking time byÂ 65%.â€

Michael Mitchell (Airtable)

â–¶Â Â Building a Teleprompter App in 30 Minutes with AI â€” Building apps with AI powered tools isnâ€™t unusual nowadays, but if youâ€™ve never been through the process, this is a good look at how it works all the way through toÂ deployment.

Kilian Ekamp

Build Fully Functional Apps in Minutes, Not Months â€” Create, run, edit, and deploy full-stack web apps withÂ Bolt.

StackBlitz sponsor

ğŸ“º Four Talks from the London TypeScript Meetup â€“ All top notch talks. Bloomberg

ğŸ“„ Optimize JS Module Loading with link rel='modulepreload' Trevor I. Lasn

ğŸ“„ Running Your Next.js SSR App on Deno Deploy Orriols and Jiang (Deno)

ğŸ“„ From Jekyll to Astro: An AI-Assisted Migration Kevin London

ğŸ› Â Code & Tools

Linkify 4.2: Link Up URLs, Emails, and More in Plain Text â€” Given plain text containing things like links, hashtags, IP addresses, and email addresses, this will generate the correct code to display it on the Web. GitHubÂ repo.

Hypercontext

Skia Canvas 2.0: A 'Browserless' Canvas Environment for Node.js â€” Based on Googleâ€™s Skia engine and offers end results similar to Chromeâ€™s own canvas system. GPU accelerated and can render images, paths, fonts, shapes, etc. v2.0 adds support for WOFF/WOFF2 fonts, WEBP, and more. GitHubÂ repo.

Christian Swinehart

Introducing <Waitlist/> Mode - A Virtual Queue for Your App â€” Launching a new product but not ready to open it up to everyone yet? Waitlist Sign-up mode is yourÂ solution.

Clerk sponsor

Math.js 14.0: An Extensive Math Library â€” Work with complex numbers, fractions, units, matrices, symbolic computation, etc. A long standing library continuing to get frequent updates. GitHubÂ repo.

Jos de Jong

Onlook: 'Figma'-Like Design App for React â€” A new open source, local-first design app (for Windows, Linux & macOS) targeting React apps. Design layouts directly on a live page and instantly write your changes to code. GitHubÂ repo.

On Off Inc.

ğŸ•’Â SpaceTime 7.7: A Lightweight Timezone Library â€” Use this to calculate times in other timezones. Has a Moment-like API but is immutable. No dependencies. Now updated for 2025. GitHubÂ repo.

Spencer Kelly

BunBuster: A Fast Web and TCP Fuzzer for Brute Forcing Servers â€” As always, use these sorts of things in a responsible way, but itâ€™s interesting to see tools like this now being built in JavaScript, thanks to Bunâ€™s speed and ease of distributingÂ binaries.

Tiago Rangel

Kaluma: A Tiny JS Runtime for the Raspberry Pi Pico â€” Can a JS runtime squeeze into 64KB to run on the RP2040-based Raspberry Pi Pico? Kaluma can, even while offering Node.js-styleÂ niceties.

Kaluma Project

Todoctor: A Tool to Analyze and Track TODO Comments â€” A CLI tool designed to collect and monitor TODO/FIXME-style comments in JavaScript and TypeScriptÂ projects. GitHub repo.

Azat S

ğŸ“°Â Classifieds

ğŸª Hookdeck: A serverless queue to reliably send, receive, transform, filter, and route events across your event-drivenÂ apps.

Meticulous automatically creates & maintains E2E UI tests. Zero flakes. Used by Lattice, Bilt Rewards andÂ others.

  • ğŸ PythonMonkey 1.1 â€“ Embed the SpiderMonkey JS engine into Python'sÂ VM.

  • nrm 1.5 â€“ Fast switching between registries: npm, cnpm, nj,Â taobao.

  • LogTape 0.8 â€“ Simple logging library for all major JSÂ runtimes.

  • Faker 9.3 â€“ Generate fabricated data to your heart'sÂ content.

  • np 10.1 â€“ A better npmÂ publish. Now supports BunÂ too.

  • DOCX 9.1 â€“ Generate .docx / WordÂ files fromÂ JavaScript.

  • Preact 10.25 â€“ The 3KB React-compatibleÂ alternative.

items.title: Exploring JavaScript symbols
items.content:
#â€‹714 â€” November 21, 2024

Read on the Web

ğŸ¦ƒ We're taking next week off for Thanksgiving. We don't celebrate it in our country, but we know many of you do, so it seemed a good time for a break. We'll be back on Thursday DecemberÂ 5.
__
Your editor, Peter Cooper

JavaScript Weekly

Importing a Frontend JavaScript Library Without a Build System â€” Many developers prefer to eschew complex, modern build processes and use JavaScript in a more old-school way. You can definitely get by without a build system, and Julia explores some ways to import libraries in such aÂ setup.

Julia Evans

Angular v19 Released â€” The latest version of the popular enterprise-scale app framework is here with a â–¶ï¸ 22 minute introductory video running through whatâ€™s changed and whatâ€™s new, including incremental hydration (in preview), two new core reactivity primitives, event replay, and the ability to specify which routes are rendered server or clientÂ side.

Minko Gechev

Ship Code Confidently When You Take Testing Fundamentals â€” Join Steve Kinney for this video course on test-driven development workflows and nail the testing fundamentals. You'll learn about automation, equality, mocks and spies, integration testing, the tools to help you along the way, and muchÂ more.

Frontend Masters sponsor

IN BRIEF:

  • ğŸ—³ï¸ The latest State of JS survey is now open and taking your responses. It's open until DecemberÂ 3.

  • ğŸ‡«ğŸ‡· dotJS 2025 is taking place next April in Paris,Â France. If you'd like to speak, the CFP is open until NovemberÂ 29.

  • AWS Lambda, the serverless functions platform, turns ten years old this week. Its first runtime wasÂ JavaScript-based.

  • Nova is an interesting new JavaScript engine that takes a CPU cache friendly data-orientedÂ approach.

RELEASES:

  • Bun v1.1.35 â€“ The fast JavaScriptCore-based runtime adds native support for Musl and Alpine Linux, the Bun binary is a lot smaller, console.group and groupEnd are now supported, and fs.readFile is faster on smallÂ files.

  • Payload 3.0 â€“ Headless Next.js-native CMSÂ platform.

  • ğŸ“Š Mantine v7.14.0 â€“ The popular React component suite adds new 'angle slider', radial bar chart, funnel chart, and stacking modal/drawer components.

  • Node.js v23.3.0 (Current) and v20.18.1 (LTS)

  • Ionic 8.4, ESLint v9.15.0, Turborepo 2.3, Deno 2.1, QuickJS 0.7

  • ğŸ¤ It wasn't released by the time we hit 'send' but we suspect TypeScript 5.7 will be out later today â€“ you can check on the TypeScriptÂ blog.

ğŸ“’Â Articles & Tutorials

Exploring JavaScript Symbols â€” Symbols were a new â€˜quirky little primitiveâ€™ (as Trevor puts it) that arrived with ES6 ten years ago, but they continue to be poorly understood. Trevor boils them down really well, including a little side quest into the likely-to-be-deprecated â€˜species.â€™

Trevor I. Lasn

Breakpoints and console.log Is the Past, Time Travel Is the Future â€” Next-level testing in any editor, 15x faster with Interactive Time Travel Debugger, real-time insights & advanced coverage in a newÂ UI.

Wallaby Team sponsor

Building Self-Contained Executable Programs with Deno â€” One of Denoâ€™s compelling features is its deno compile command that can turn JavaScript and TypeScript programs into single, easy to distribute cross-platform binaries. Hereâ€™s a bit more about what makes itÂ tick.

Ryan Dahl and Andy Jiang

Mapping Over Promises in JavaScript â€” A quick look at three approaches: for..of, Promise.all, and p-map

Peter Mbanugo

Explore Sentry Launch Week: New Products and CommunityÂ Highlights â€” Join us for daily video drops on YouTube at 9am PT, and on Discord to chat live with the engineers buildingÂ Sentry.

Sentry sponsor

ğŸ“„ Migrating from VuePress to VitePress Henry Bley-Vroman

ğŸ“„ Why Alpine is the 'New jQuery' and Why That's Awesome Raymond Camden

ğŸ“„ How to Prerelease an npm Package Scott Vandehey

ğŸ“„ Precise Decimal Math in JavaScript with Fraction.js Trevor I. Lasn

ğŸ“„ How to Avoid Flaky Tests in Playwright Zanini and Ackerson

ğŸ“„ Adding Interactive Charts in Astro Pavlin BG

ğŸ› Â Code & Tools

Viselect: Let Users Visually Select DOM Elements â€” If youâ€™ve got a variety of elements and you want users to be able to select them in groups, individually, or even in multiple groups, this lets you offer that functionality easily. Can be used in a vanilla fashion or with integrations for P/React orÂ Vue.js.

Simon Reinisch

Perfectionist 4: ESLint Plugin for Sorting Things in YourÂ Code â€” It doesnâ€™t care what you want to sort (props, imports, types, decorators, modules..) but if you want to enforce something is sorted using ESLint, this is for you. It supports alphabetical and natural sorting, plus sorting by line length which results in this sort ofÂ aesthetic.

Azat S.

Your Vectors Are Too Big â€” Are your massive full-fidelity vectors slowing down your search? Compress, cut costs, and boost speed with MongoDBÂ Atlas!

MongoDB sponsor

React Scan: Detect Performance Issues in Your App â€” A pure JavaScript tool you can drop into your app to automatically â€˜scanâ€™ for problematic renders without doing lots of integration work. Thereâ€™s a simple demo on the homepage or you can see Aidenâ€™s view of Twitter/X being scanned. GitHubÂ repo.

Aiden Bai

ğŸ’¬Â Discordeno v19: A Powerful Discord API Library â€” A long-standing way to work with, and build bots for, the popular Discord chat system. v19 is a big update with breaking changes. GitHubÂ repo.

Discordeno Team

ğŸ¤–Â Vercel's AI Chatbot Starter Template â€” An open source AI chatbot app template built using Next.js. It uses Vercelâ€™s AI SDK and other Vercel APIs for the heavyÂ lifting.

Vercel

Glide.js 3.7: A Dependency-Free Slider and Carousel Control â€” â€œDesigned to slide. No less, no moreâ€ says the creator. MIT licensed andÂ mature.

JÄ™drzej ChaÅ‚ubek

ğŸ“°Â Classifieds

Meticulous automatically creates & maintains E2E UI tests. Zero flakes. Used by Lattice, Bilt Rewards andÂ others.

Hookdeck: An alternative to Amazon API Gateway + Lambda + SQS. With local dev, debugging, and observabilityÂ built-in.

  • pretty-ms 9.2 â€“ Convert milliseconds to human readable strings. Now with options to hide years, seconds and days, asÂ preferred.

  • â˜• Javet 4.1 â€“ Embed Node.js and V8 intoÂ Java. Updates to Node v22.11.0 and adds Float16Â support.

  • Embla Carousel 8.5 â€“ Lightweight carousel library with fluid motion.

  • Sortable 4.0 â€“ Make tables sortable withÂ class="sortable"

  • ğŸ“Š Vue Data UI 2.4 â€“ Vue 3 data visualizationÂ components.

  • Capacitor 6.2 â€“ Build cross-platform native apps withÂ JS.

  • Peggy 4.2 â€“ Parser generator for JavaScript.

Ryan Dahl and Andy Jiang 


  
  
Mapping Over Promises in JavaScript â€” A quick look at three approaches: for..of, Promise.all, and p-map
Peter Mbanugo 


  
  
Explore Sentry Launch Week: New Products and CommunityÂ Highlights â€” Join us for daily video drops on YouTube at 9am PT, and on Discord to chat live with the engineers buildingÂ Sentry.
Sentry sponsor


ğŸ“„ Migrating from VuePress to VitePress  Henry Bley-Vroman
ğŸ“„ Why Alpine is the 'New jQuery' and Why That's Awesome  Raymond Camden
ğŸ“„ How to Prerelease an npm Package  Scott Vandehey
ğŸ“„ Precise Decimal Math in JavaScript with Fraction.js  Trevor I. Lasn
ğŸ“„ How to Avoid Flaky Tests in Playwright  Zanini and Ackerson
ğŸ“„ Adding Interactive Charts in Astro  Pavlin BG


ğŸ› Â Code & Tools




  





  
  
Viselect: Let Users Visually Select DOM Elements â€” If youâ€™ve got a variety of elements and you want users to be able to select them in groups, individually, or even in multiple groups, this lets you offer that functionality easily. Can be used in a vanilla fashion or with integrations for P/React orÂ Vue.js.
Simon Reinisch 


  
  
Perfectionist 4: ESLint Plugin for Sorting Things in YourÂ Code â€” It doesnâ€™t care what you want to sort (props, imports, types, decorators, modules..) but if you want to enforce something is sorted using ESLint, this is for you. It supports alphabetical and natural sorting, plus sorting by line length which results in this sort ofÂ aesthetic.
Azat S. 


  
  
Your Vectors Are Too Big â€” Are your massive full-fidelity vectors slowing down your search? Compress, cut costs, and boost speed with MongoDBÂ Atlas!
MongoDB sponsor


  
  
React Scan: Detect Performance Issues in Your App â€” A pure JavaScript tool you can drop into your app to automatically â€˜scanâ€™ for problematic renders without doing lots of integration work. Thereâ€™s a simple demo on the homepage or you can see Aidenâ€™s view of Twitter/X being scanned. GitHubÂ repo.
Aiden Bai 


  
  
ğŸ’¬Â Discordeno v19: A Powerful Discord API Library â€” A long-standing way to work with, and build bots for, the popular Discord chat system. v19 is a big update with breaking changes. GitHubÂ repo.
Discordeno Team 


  
  
ğŸ¤–Â Vercel's AI Chatbot Starter Template â€” An open source AI chatbot app template built using Next.js. It uses Vercelâ€™s AI SDK and other Vercel APIs for the heavyÂ lifting.
Vercel 


  
  
Glide.js 3.7: A Dependency-Free Slider and Carousel Control â€” â€œDesigned to slide. No less, no moreâ€ says the creator. MIT licensed andÂ mature.
JÄ™drzej ChaÅ‚ubek 








	
ğŸ“°Â Classifieds


Meticulous automatically creates & maintains E2E UI tests. Zero flakes. Used by Lattice, Bilt Rewards andÂ others.
Hookdeck: An alternative to Amazon API Gateway + Lambda + SQS. With local dev, debugging, and observabilityÂ built-in.












pretty-ms 9.2 â€“ Convert milliseconds to human readable strings. Now with options to hide years, seconds and days, asÂ preferred.
â˜• Javet 4.1 â€“ Embed Node.js and V8 intoÂ Java. Updates to Node v22.11.0 and adds Float16Â support.
Embla Carousel 8.5 â€“ Lightweight carousel library with fluid motion.
Sortable 4.0 â€“ Make tables sortable withÂ class="sortable"
ğŸ“Š Vue Data UI 2.4 â€“ Vue 3 data visualizationÂ components.
Capacitor 6.2 â€“ Build cross-platform native apps withÂ JS.
Peggy 4.2 â€“ Parser generator for JavaScript.

items.title: Will we care about frameworks in an AI world?
items.content:
#â€‹713 â€” November 14, 2024

Read on the Web

JavaScript Weekly

Component Party: A Rosetta Stone of UI Libraries â€” A long-standing comparison of many different frameworks (like React, Vue, Svelte, Angular, Qwik, Solid.js, etc.) by way of simple code snippets to perform various tasks. Now including SvelteÂ 5 and AngularÂ 17/Renaissance.

Mathieu Schimmerling

Will We Care About Frameworks in the Future? â€” Paul wonders if the increasing use of LLMs and agents in software development will lead to a reduction in the need for new frameworks and extra developer-focusedÂ abstractions.

Paul Kinlan

Advanced JavaScript Tools to Empower Your Applications â€” Build better web applications with powerful JavaScript developer tools including: SpreadJS Excel-like spreadsheet components, ActiveReportsJS reporting tools, Wijmo UI component suite, and Document Solutions viewers for PDF, Excel, Image, andÂ more.

MESCIUS inc sponsor

The vlt Package Manager and Serverless Registry â€” A very experienced team, including npm creator Isaac Schlueter, launched Vlt to â€˜build the futureâ€™ of JavaScript package management. The first results have appeared in the shape of the vlt client (which can replace npm), as well as a serverless package registry you can self host to serve up your ownÂ packages.

Clarke, Adorno, Schlueter, and Karrys

ğŸ’¡ Sarah Gooding shares some more background on Vlt's storyÂ here.

TypeScript 5.7 Release Candidate â€” The popular typed JS superset adds support for ES2024 as a target, can report errors when variables aren't initialized, adds path rewriting for relative paths, and can use Nodeâ€™s compile caching to save on parsing work. The final release is expected in a week orÂ two.

Microsoft

IN BRIEF:

  • ğŸ¤– Microsoft has introduced Copilot Edits in VS Code â€“ it provides a way to work across multiple files in a project at once.

  • Jawsm is an early-stage, experimental JavaScript to WebAssembly compiler (akin to Porffor) but that aims to use the most advanced WASM features off the bat, such as WasmGC and exception handling.

  • ğŸ’œ CSS now has an official logo!

RELEASES:

  • Expo SDK 52 â€“ Toolset for building modern React Native apps, now supporting React Native 0.76 and the NewÂ Architecture.

  • Node.js v18.20.5 (LTS) â€“ Lots of dependency updates and now import attributes and JSON modules are markedÂ stable.

  • No announcement, but it looks like Ember 6.0 is about to land.

  • Node.js v23.2.0 (Current), pnpm 9.13, Parcel 2.13.0

ğŸ“’Â Articles & Tutorials

JavaScript Import Attributes (ES2025) Explained â€” Import Attributes (now at stage 4 at TC39 and already supported in some runtimes) add a way to supply useful metadata about modules youâ€™reÂ importing.

Trevor I. Lasn

ğŸ’¡ Trevor is on quite a run of great posts. He also digs into Promise.try and how JavaScript's bitwise shifting operatorsÂ work.

Creating an ASCII Shader Using OGL â€” An incredibly cool effect demonstrated in a great tutorial on getting started with shaders and using OGL, a lightweight WebGLÂ library.

Andrico Karoulla

Guide to Error & Exception Handling in React â€” Learn common errors and best practices for recovering from them in a user-friendlyÂ way.

Sentry sponsor

How a BBC Navigation Bar Component Broke Depending on Which External Monitor It Was On â€” A look at an interesting bug related to external monitor positioning. The lesson is that â€œbrowsers have an interoperability issue in how they represent screen coordinates in multi-monitorÂ setupsâ€.

Josh Tumath

How to Set Up Next.js 15 for Production in 2024 â€” Share in this authorâ€™s experience in scaling up Next.js apps to over 100k monthly active users and millions of monthlyÂ visitors.

Jan Hesters (ReactSquad)

â–¶Â Â From Next.js to htmx: A Real World Example â€” An interesting case study explained in a 50-minute screencast: â€œReplacing my components with the equivalent HTML elements powered by htmx wasnâ€™t exactly an easy task, but one that was worth theÂ time.â€

Pouria Ezzati

ğŸ“„ How to Optimize Performance in Vue Apps Jakub Andrzejewski

ğŸ“„ How to Build a Database App with Drizzle ORM and Deno Andy Jiang

ğŸ“„ Essential tsconfig.json Options You Should Use Duy NG

ğŸ“º Building a Rich Text Editor with Svelte 5 Michael Aufreiter

ğŸ› Â Code & Tools

Lexical 0.20: An Easy-to-Extend Text Editor Framework from Meta â€” A text editor framework built by Meta with extensibility, accessibility, and cross platform support in mind (thereâ€™s even a Swift variant for iOS). Thereâ€™s a live playground if you want to give it a try. React support is first class, but it can be adapted to work elsewhere (as with svelte-lexical).

Meta / Facebook

Introducing @clerk/nextjs v6, with Support for Next.js 15 â€” With v6, auth() helper is async, <ClerkProvider> defaults to static rendering, and partial pre-rendering isÂ supported.

Clerk sponsor

Storybook 8.4 Released â€” A minor release for the powerful frontend component workshop but â€œone of our most feature-packed minor releasesâ€ with one click component testing, Svelte 5 support, and React Native Storybook 8.

Michael Shilman

ğŸ—“ï¸Â Schedule-X 2.5: Material Design Calendar and Date Picker â€” Available in the form of React/Preact, Vue, Svelte, Angular, or plain JS components. Open source but with a premium version with extra features. GitHubÂ repo.

Tom Ã–sterlund

ğŸµÂ music-metadata: Stream and File-Based Music Metadata Parser â€” Supporting formats like MP3, FLAC, Ogg, WAV, WMA, AAC and AIFF, this library extracts metadata like ID3v1 and iTunes tags for processing however you want. Yes, it even works in theÂ browser.

Borewit

Looking for a DIY Survey Solution? SurveyJS Has You Covered â€” Build, customize, and store surveys with ease. Total data control, JSON-driven, no backend restrictionsâ€”integrates into any JavaScriptÂ app.

SurveyJS sponsor

Micromark 4.0.1: A Small Compliant Markdown Parser â€” 100% compliance with the CommonMark standard, supports extensions (such as for GitHub Flavored Markdown), and full testÂ coverage.

Titus Wormer

jsep 1.4: JavaScript Expression Parser â€” â€œThink of jsep as a tool to parse the kinds of expressions that would be written in individual ExcelÂ cells.â€

Stephen Oney

  • ğŸ“Š visx 3.12 â€“ Airbnb's suite of React visualization components now includes a Sankey diagramÂ component.

  • ğŸ–¼ï¸ Fabric.js 6.5 â€“ Makes HTML5 Canvas elements more interactive with an object model and operations. GitHubÂ repo.

  • DOMPurify 3.2 â€“ Fast, tolerant XSS sanitizer for HTML andÂ SVG. Demo.

  • MikroORM 6.4 â€“ Popular TypeScriptÂ ORM forÂ Node.js.

  • Marked 15.0 â€“ Fast Markdown compilerÂ /Â parser.

ğŸ“°Â Classifieds

ğŸ¹ STRICH: Add blazing fast and reliable 1D/2D Barcode Scanning to your web apps. Free demo app and 30-day trialÂ available.

Never miss a Shopify, Stripe, GitHub, Paddleâ€¦ or any webhook again with Hookdeck's serverless queue infrastructure. LearnÂ more.

Meticulous automatically creates & maintains E2E UI tests. Zero flakes. Used by Lattice, Bilt Rewards andÂ others.

ğŸ˜€Â More fun at Val Town

I've written about Val Town several times and am a huge fan. It's a site where you can write and deploy TypeScript from your browser and describes itself as "if GitHub Gists could run, and AWS Lambda was fun."

It's been a delight to watch its progression from a prototype to what is now a solid platform used in production use cases and I want to call out some recent posts that keep it on my radar:

Building a Code-Writing Robot and Keeping it Happy â€“ Townie is an AI assistant for building apps on Val Town. This post digs into how it works, some of the problems encountered in its creation, and how its results areÂ evaluated.

Val Town Town â€“ Could you implement something like Val Town on Val Town itself? At the risk of eating its own tail, it turns out you can.

If you're stuck for something to do or check out, check out Val Town â€“ it'sÂ fun!

items.title: JSConf is back
items.content:
#â€‹712 â€” November 7, 2024

Read on the Web

JavaScript Weekly

JavaScript's ??= Operator: Default Values Made Simple â€” The ??= nullish coalescing assignment operator snuck into JavaScript a few years ago via ECMAScript 2021 and has been broadly supported almost everywhere for ages. Trevor shows off how it can tighten up your assignmentsÂ here.

Trevor I. Lasn

ğŸ’¡ He also took a similar look at the pipeline operator |>, but this feature is still only in draft as aÂ proposal.

ğŸ‡ºğŸ‡¸Â JSConf is Back; Here's the Details â€” Two months ago, the OpenJS Foundation announced that the popular JSConf brand was joining the foundation and a new North American JSConf event would happen in due course. Now you can mark your calendars for October 14-16, 2025 for an event taking place in the Chesapeake Bay area of Maryland, USA.

OpenJS Foundation

Handsontable: A Powerful Data Grid for InternalÂ Apps â€” Speed up the development of your React app with a feature-rich data grid - sorting, filtering, multiple cell types, built-in formulas, CRUD operations, and an extensive API. Come visit our booth at React Summit US on Nov 19th to see it inÂ action!

Handsontable sponsor

Announcing Rspack 1.1 â€” Rspack is a fast, Rust-powered alternative to Webpack but with the same API. v1.1 boasts being 10% faster than v1.0 and has an improved, though still experimental, incremental build feature. If super fast build times are your bag, this needs to be on yourÂ radar.

The Rspack Team

IN BRIEF:

  • ğŸ† The OpenJS Foundation has honored six JavaScript developers with awards in categories including Unsung Hero and Pathfinder forÂ Education.

  • The working group behind the JSR package registry has met to outline plans for an open governance model and a roadmap to enhance JS packageÂ management.

  • âš ï¸ Phylum takes a look at yet another (ongoing) typosquatting campaign to try and trick JavaScript developers into installing malicious packages.

  • There's fewer than two weeks left to take the State of React 2024 survey.

  • Storybook offers a sneak peek at their Storybook Test tool for fast UIÂ testing.

RELEASES:

  • VitePress 1.5 â€“ Evan You's Vite and Vue-powered static site generator.

  • create-vue 3.12 â€“ The recommended way to start a Vite-powered Vue project. Now with an experimental OxlintÂ integration.

  • ESLint v9.14.0 â€“ Now supporting import attributes and regexpÂ modifiers.

  • Mermaid 11.4 â€“ The popular diagram / charting tool adds KanbanÂ diagrams.

  • React Navigation 7, Electron 33.1, TinyMCE 7.5.0, Bun v1.1.34

ğŸ“’Â Articles & Tutorials

Wasmer Adds Node.js and Bun Support â€” Wasmer is a Rust-powered WebAssembly runtime and Wasmer 5.0 adds V8 and JavaScriptCore backend support, meaning you can try all sorts of things like, say, running Clang, Python, or even compiled JavaScript apps inside your own JavaScript app..

Syrus Akbary

Why Would Anyone Need Generator Functions? â€” A golden oldie that I enjoyed revisiting because it covers an oft misunderstood and not particularly commonly encountered JavaScriptÂ feature.

James Sinclair

Breakpoints and console.log Is the Past, Time Travel Is theÂ Future â€” Next-level testing in any editor, 15x faster with Interactive Time Travel Debugger, real-time insights & advanced coverage in a newÂ UI.

Wallaby Team sponsor

The Most Effective Ways to Improve Core Web Vitals â€” Everyone wants their site to be as performant as possible, especially when Google factors performance into its rankings, but how? Google shares a variety of practical techniques to improve your INP, LCP, and CLS metricsÂ here.

Google

Why Code Security Matters - Even in Hardened Environments â€” A well diagrammed dive into a technique that allows malicious parties to turn a file write vulnerability in a Node.js app into a remote code execution exploit even when the file system isÂ read-only.

Stefan Schiller (Sonar)

Generating Random Mazes with JavaScript â€” A fun, well-presented walkthrough of a basic maze generationÂ process.

Paul Hebert

Along similarly fun lines is Chris MMO's Generating Lever-DoorÂ Puzzles.

MongoDB Helps Devs Build Better AI Agents with LangChain & HybridÂ Search â€” Itâ€™s easier than ever to build AI agents with LangChain, perform hybrid search and ingest large-scaleÂ documents.

MongoDB sponsor

ğŸš— Hacking Cars in JavaScript â€“ Or â€œRunning Replay Attacks in the Browser with theÂ HackRF.â€ Charlie Gerard

ğŸ“„ How Bun Supports V8 APIs Without Using V8 (Part 2) Ben Grant (Bun)

ğŸ“„ How to Create an Organic Text Distortion Effect with Infinite Scrolling â€“ There's a live demo of the striking, though disorienting, effect. Jorge Toloza

ğŸ“„ Vercel Makes Changes to Next.js to Simplify Self-Hosting Loraine Lawson (The New Stack)

ğŸ“„ The Latest in Angular Change Detection â€“ All You Need to Know Krzysztof Skorupka

ğŸ› Â Code & Tools

npmpackage.info: Detailed Package Info on a Single Page â€” Give this online tool the name of an npm package and you get a quick â€˜dashboardâ€™ style view of the projectâ€™s main statistics, covering areas like quality scores, commits, open issues, releases, bundle size, andÂ more.

Shrinath Nayak

ğŸ“Š NPM Chart is another cool new site focused on showing npm package downloadÂ stats.

Prompt, Run, Edit, and Deploy Full-Stack Web Apps with bolt.new â€” StackBlitz recently released an in-browser AI web development agent: bolt.new! Give it a tryÂ today.

StackBlitz sponsor

Docusaurus 3.6: The Docs-Oriented Static Site Generator â€” Metaâ€™s Docusaurus is a popular way to build docs sites (like these). v3.6 is focused on performance, now using tools like Rspack and SWC to make builds superÂ fast.

Meta

Immutable.js 5.0: Immutable Collections for JavaScript â€” Provides numerous persistent immutable data structures including a list, stack, map, ordered map, set, ordered set, andÂ records.

Lee Byron and Contributors

Sonner 1.7: The Toast Notification React Component â€” Thereâ€™s a live demo to try on the homepage, or see the GitHub repo. v1.7 focuses on animation improvements, browser support, and ReactÂ 19.

Emil Kowalski

Quaternion.js: A JavaScript Quaternion library â€” Last week we featured the authorâ€™s Fraction.js library, now we go a step deeper with a way to work with 3D rotations using quarternions.

Robert Eisele

  • BlockNote 0.19 â€“ 'Notion-style' block-basedÂ editor. Now supporting column-based layouts and client-side export to .docx andÂ PDF. There's a demo on the project'sÂ homepage.

  • ğŸ” OpenPGP.js 6.0 â€“ OpenPGP implementation for JavaScript now supporting the new version of the OpenPGP spec, RFC 9580.

  • Fastify 5.1 â€“ The fast, low overhead Node.js webÂ framework.

  • xr 6.4 â€“ Bring VR/AR to React ThreeÂ FiberÂ apps.

ğŸ“°Â Classifieds

âš™ï¸ Create entire web apps with Reactile and let it handle your widgets and windows within a single browser tab. 1-month free trial. Try it now.

Meticulous automatically creates & maintains E2E UI tests. Zero flakes. Used by Lattice, Bilt Rewards and others.

Pythagora is an AI dev tool that builds production-ready tools (not demo apps). It writes the code and talks to you in the process.

ğŸ“—Â We're also reading..

We've also had some tabs open that aren't JavaScript specific but you might find interesting nonetheless:

ğŸ«£ Weird Lexical Syntax by Justine Tunney. Justine is building a syntax highlighter and set out to learn 42 programming languages in a single month to help figure out the edge cases. She recounts the surprising things she discovered about the syntax of various languages, includingÂ JavaScript.

ğŸ‘» Before You Buy a Domain, Check if it's Haunted by Bryan Braun. Buying a domain for a side project is always fun, but it's far less fun when the domain was previously used for nefarious purposes and comes withÂ baggage..

ğŸ¤” What Has Case Distinction But is Neither Uppercase or Lowercase? by Raymond Chen. It sounds like a riddle, but there are actually Unicode characters that have case distinction yet are neither uppercase nor lowercaseÂ themselves.
